tei:dateline.tei:note: The first semester began, as usual, in early October. According to his diary, Schenker informed his pupils of their lesson times on September 28 and started teaching by October 3.

tei:div.tei:ab: Bach: Em-Präludium u. Fuge, neu; Mozart: Klavierkonzert Adur; Brahms: Walzer; Schubert: Impromtus u. Moments Musicaux: Asd, Asd, Fm, Cism, Fm.
Bach: Prelude & Fugue in E minor, new; Mozart: Piano Concerto in A major; Brahms: Waltz[es?]; Schubert: Impromptus and Musical Moments: A major, A major, F minor, C minor, F minor.

op. 101,Schenker's Erläuterungsausgabe of Beethoven's Piano Sonata Op. 101 (published August 1921) includes a substantial analysis that was, according to his diary, dictated in part on 19 October 1919 and completed on 20 June 1920 ‒ thus during the 1919/20 saison. neu, Mitte Januar abgeschlossen; Chaconne-OppelPresumably this was the Chaconne enclosed in Reinhard Oppel's letter to Schenker from 7 September 1919. The letter survives (OJ 13/10[7]), but the Chaconne is missing.; Schubert: Müller-Lieder (vgl. mit Wächter,In September 1919, Eberhard von Wächter gave Schenker two copies of a book on Schubert that he had written (see diary entries for September 13, 16, and 20). Presumably this was Wächter's monograph Franz Schuberts Liederzyklus "Die schöne Müllerin": Eine anaytisch-kritische Studie (Leipzig: C.F.W. Siegel, 1919). 28.I. zuende). Schubert: Impromtus: Asd, Gd.
Op. 101, new, completed in the middle of January; Oppel Chaconne; Schubert: Müller-Lieder (compare to Wächter, completed January 28). Schubert: Impromptus: A major, G major

strenger Satz; Appassionata; zum Lied als Beispiel Schuberts „Ihr Bild”This song was the subject of an unpublished analysis by Schenker dating from ca. 1906 (OC 31/436) and of a well-known article in the first issue of Der Tonwille (1921). According to Schenker's diary, he submitted the latter analysis to Universal Edition on 10 November 1920; zum Generalbass einige erste Worte; zur Fuge einige erste Worte; Mozart: Sonate Am.
Strict composition; "Appassionata"; on the Lied, with Schubert's "Ihr Bild" as an example; a few initial words on thoroughbass; a few initial words on fugue; Mozart: Sonata in A minor.
Mozart: Sonate Ad; Beethoven: Son. Ad.
Mozart: Sonata in A major; Beethoven: Sonata in A major.

tei:div.tei:head: Gärtner::
tei:div.tei:ab: Kontrapunkt Fortsetzung, 4-stimmiger Satz u. MischungsgattungOn combination-types (i.e., combinations of the five species of strict counterpoint), see Bridges to Free Composition in Schenker, Counterpoint, Book 2..
Further study of counterpoint: four-part counterpoint and combination-types.

Vorbereitung zum KonzertSchenker's diary suggests the concert took place on 5 November 2019: "An Hupka (pn. K.): beglückwünsche ihm zum ersten Abend u. erkläre ihm, weshalb ich doch nicht erschienen bin." ("To Hupka (pneumatic postcard): congratulate him on the first evening and explain why I wasn't there after all.") Presumably the concert took place at the Wiener Konzerthaus, as this was the location of a rehearsal that Schenker attended on 3 November. Exceptionally, Hupka was permitted to begin his lessons early, on September 23, because of his upcoming concert.; neu:
Brahms: Konzert Dm; Beethoven: op. 81; Schumann: Etude symphonique (beg. 27.I.);
Chromatische Fantasie, neu; wiederholt: Chopin: Nocturne; neu: Beethoven Sonate Dm ‒ nach dem 1. Satz ausgesprungen.
Chromatic Fantasy, new; revisited: Chopin: Nocturne; new: Beethoven Sonata in D minor ‒ gave up after the first movement.

wiederholt: op. 109, Chopin: Nocturne Esd, op. 101,Schenker's Erläuterungsausgabe of Beethoven's Op. 101 (published August 1921) includes a substantial analysis that was, according to his diary, dictated in part on 19 October 1919 and completed on 20 June 1920—thus during the 1919/20 saison. Berceuse, sämtliche Chopin-Etudes op. 10; Fragen aus Beethovens Pathetique; wiederholt Chopins Etudes op. 25; neu: Schubert: Impromtus u. Moments; Fragen aus Chopin Nocturne Hd; wiederholt Waldstein-Sonate, Brahms-Händel-Variationen, Beethoven Cm-Variationen, Brahms: Walzer, Beethoven: Mondschein-Sonate.

Revisited: Op. 109, Chopin: Nocturne in E major, Op. 101, Berceuse, complete Chopin Etudes Op. 10; questions on Beethoven's "Pathétique"; revisited: Chopin's Etudes Op. 25; new: Schubert: Impromptus and Moments [Musicaux]; questions on Chopin's Nocturne in B major; revisited: "Waldstein" Sonata, Brahms Handel Variations, Beethoven Variations in C minor, Brahms: Waltzes?, Beethoven: "Moonlight" Sonata.

wiederholt: Beethoven-Variationen Cm; Brahms: Intermezzo Cd, Chopin: zwei Préludes, Etude Cm aus op. 10; Brahms:
Walzer, neu; wiederholt: Appassionata, Sonate Dm; Bach: Esm Präludium, neuA brief diary entry from March 10, 1920 suggests that Schenker's analysis of this piece, published in Tonwille 1 (1921), was underway during the 1919/20 saison: "Korrektur des Es moll-Präludiums" ("Corrections to the Prelude in E minor").; Variation serieus, Mendelssohn, neu.

Revisited: Beethoven Variations in C minor; Brahms: Intermezzo in C major, Chopin: two Preludes, Etude in C minor from Op. 10; Brahms:
Waltzes?, new; revisited: "Appassionata," Sonata in D minor; Bach: Prelude in E minor, new; Variation serieus, Mendelssohn, new.

Kontrapunkt; Harmonielehre, dazu Beispiele aus op. 101Schenker's Erläuterungsausgabe of Beethoven's Op. 101 (published August 1921) includes a substantial analysis that was, according to his diary, dictated in part on 19 October 1919 and completed on 20 June 1920 ‒ thus during the 1919/20 saison., Schubert, Mozart: Sonate Am.
Counterpoint; theory of harmony, with examples from Op. 101, Schubert, Mozart: Sonata in A minor.
Brahms-Händel-Variationen, neu (abgeschl. Mitte Januar). Bach: Präludium u. Fuge Cm, neu; Beethoven: Appassionata wiederholt, Mondschein-Sonate, neu; Bach: Präludium u. Fuge Cisd.

Brahms, Handel Variations, new (completed in the middle of January). Bach: Prelude & Fugue in C minor, new; Beethoven: "Appassionata" revisited, "Moonlight" Sonata, new; Bach: Prelude & Fugue in C major
Bach: Präludium u. Fuge Cm, neu; wiederholt: Mondschein-Sonate u. Etudes von Chopin: Fd, Gesd.
Bach: Prelude & Fugue in C minor, new; revisited: "Moonlight" Sonata and Etudes by Chopin: F major, G major
Kreutzer-Sonate; Mozart: Klavier-Violin-Sonate Bd; Chopin: Polonaise Asd wiederholt.
"Kreutzer" Sonata; Mozart: Sonata for Piano and Violin in B major; Chopin: Polonaise in A major revisited.

Kontrapunkt Fortsetzung; Schubert:
Phantasie-Sonate Gd.

Further study of counterpoint; Schubert:
Fantasy-Sonata in G major.

Choral aus Bachs Matthäus-Passion, Mittelstimmen einsetzen"einsetzten": most likely Schenker has provided the treble and bass voices of the chorale and now requires Weisse to fill in the (i.e. devise his own) alto and tenor voices.; Fugen-Studien: Wohltemperiertes Klavier: Em, Bd, Cisd, Dm. Baß zum Choral „Allein Gott in der Höhe”; Erk No 6,Ludwig Christian Erk Johann Sebastian Bachs Choralgesänge und geistliche Arien (Leipzig: Peters), Part I (1850), Part II (1865). dazu gesamte Literatur: Riemann, Vogler usw.No paragraph-break in original.

Chopin: Berçeuse, neu; Mozart: Sonate Am; Fragen, meist Linien, Stufen usw. betreffend aus Beethoven op. 2, No 1 aus Anlaß eines Aufsatz (gegen Riemann)Schenker's own critique of Riemann's analysis appears in Beethoven: Sonate opus 2 Nr. 1, in: Der Tonwille Heft 2 (1922), pp. 46‒48; Eng. transl. vol. I, pp. 92‒94. ; zum Aufsatz gegen Busoni über das System,This relates to Weisse's own rebuttal to Ferruccio Busoni's Entwurf einer neuen Ästhetik der Tonkunst (Triest: Schmidl & Co., 1907). For further details, see the diary entries from 4, 6, and 11 October 1919. Fragen aus op. 106, Adagio; Mozart: Rondo Am; Schubert: Sonate Bd; Kreutzer-Sonate; Beethoven op. 2 No 3, alle Sätze; Sonate Esd, Cm, Leonoren-Ouverture; Sonate Fd, op. 10; Sonate Dd; Brahms: Sextett Bd.

Chorale from Bach's St. Matthew Passion, inner voices to be filled in; fugue studies: Well-tempered Clavier: E minor, B major, C major, D minor. Bass to the chorale "Allein Gott in der Höhe"; Erk No. 6, and the entire literature about it: Riemann, Vogler, etc.

Chopin: Berçeuse, new; Mozart: Sonata in A minor; questions, mostly about lines, scale-steps, etc., concerning Beethoven Op. 2, No. 1 on the occasion of an essay (against Riemann); on to an essay against Busoni on his system, questions on Op. 106, Adagio; Mozart: Rondo in A minor; Schubert: Sonata in B major; "Kreutzer" Sonata; Beethoven Op. 2, No. 3, all movements; Sonatas in E major, C minor, "Leonore" Overture; Sonata in F major, Op. 10; Sonata in D major; Brahms: Sextet in B major.

Schubert: Bdur mit Variationen; Schumann: Waldszenen, neu: Vogel als Prophet, einsame Blumen, Verrufene Stelle, Herberge, Abschied; Schumann: Phantasiestücke: Des Abends, In der Nacht; Chopin: Polonaise, Cismoll, Linie.Several linear sketches of this work survive in the Oster Collection. Four of these sketches, namely OC 32/62‒65, appear to date from ca. 1920 based on their notational style.

Schubert: Impromptu in B major with variations; Schumann: Waldszenen, new: Vogel als Prophet, Einsame Blumen, Verrufene Stelle, Herberge, Abschied; Schumann: Phantasiestücke: Des Abends, In der Nacht; Chopin: Polonaise in C minor, line.

Schubert: Impromptu Asdur u. Bdur mit Variationen, Gesdur. Bach: Cmoll-Präludium II. Bd; Linie, Harmonien; Schubert: CismollPossibly the Moment musical in C minor, Op. 94, No. 4, a piece that Brünauer had studied in the first semester.; Beethoven: Diabelli-Variationen; Brahms: Intermezzo, Autograph erklärtPresumably this was from the autograph of Brahms's Three Intermezzi, Op. 117, mentioned in the entry on Schaab's lessons from this semester. According to Schenker's diary, he received photographs of Op. 117 from Hans Weisse on February 24, 1920, the day before he finished dictating an essay on the Intermezzo in E major, Op. 117, No. 1. The essay survives as OC 34/83‒105.; Dwořak: Legenden vierhändig; Bach: zweistimmige Emoll-Fuge; Schumann: Des Abends; Chopin: Polonaise Cismoll, Linie; Schumann: Warum?; Beethoven: Bagatellen Asdur, Bdur, Adur, Cmoll.

Schubert: Impromptus in A major, B major with variations, G major. Bach: C minor Prelude from Book II; line, harmonies; Schubert: C minor; Beethoven: Diabelli Variations; Brahms: Intermezzo, autograph explained; Dvořák: Legends played four-hands; Bach: two-voiced fugue in E minor; Schumann: Des Abends; Chopin: Polonaise in C minor, line; Schumann: Warum?; Beethoven: Bagatelles in A major, B major, A major, C minor.

dreist. Fuge, Thema nach Nottebohm, S. 76Probably a reference to Gustav Nottebohm, Beethovens Studien, Erster Band: Beethoven's Unterricht bei J. Haydn, Albrechtsberger und Salieri (Leipzig: Rieter-Biedermann, 1873). The section on three-voiced fugue is found on pp. 89‒94, but p. 76 (from the section on two-voiced fugue) does include a fugue subject ("Nr. 3"). Perhaps Schenker had Figdor compose a three-voiced fugue based on this subject.; Beethoven: Sonate Gdur op. 14 letzter Satz (Linie); Beethoven: op. 59, Adagio;
Fmoll: Form u. StufenPresumably Op. 2, No. 1, the subject of an analysis that Schenker prepared the following year, beginning in March 1921, and published in Tonwille 2 (1922).; Haydn: Fmoll mit Variationen; MischungsgattungenOn combination-types (i.e., combinations of the five species of strict counterpoint), see Bridges to Free Composition in Schenker, Counterpoint, Book 2.; Chopin: Berceuse; Generalbaß; Bach: Präludium Cmoll Bd. I; Präludium Esm.A brief diary entry from 10 March 1920 suggests that Schenker's analysis of this piece, published in Tonwille 1 (1921), was underway during the 1919/20 saison: "Korrektur des Es moll-Präludiums" ("Corrections to the Prelude in E-flat minor"). Chopin: Polonaise Asdur, UrlinienskizzeThis is the first appearance of the term "Urlinie" in Schenker's lessonbooks. The earliest published writings that use this word, namely the Erläuterunsgausgabe of Beethoven's Op. 101 and the first issue of Der Tonwille, were both completed during the 1919/20 saison. The Urlinie sketch in question may be one of OC 32/77‒80 . dazu; spielt auch die Polonaise; Beethoven: Sonate Ddur op. 10, Anfang; Mondscheinsonate, Allegretto, Anfang.

Three-voiced fugue, theme from Nottebohm, page 76; Beethoven: Sonata in G major, Op. 14, last movement (line); Beethoven: Op. 59, Adagio;
F minor : form and scale-steps; Haydn: F minor with variations; combination-types; Chopin: Berceuse; thoroughbass; Bach: Prelude in C minor from Book I; Prelude in E minor. Chopin: Polonaise in A major, Urlinie sketch thereof; also plays the Polonaise; Beethoven: Sonata in D major from Op. 10, beginning; "Moonlight" Sonata, Allegretto, beginning.
Chopin: Polonaise Cismoll.
Chopin: Polonaise in C minor.

tei:div.tei:head: Gärtner::
tei:div.tei:ab: Lieder von Schubert u. Brahms zu einem Konzertzweck, Lieder von Wolf, Brahms Volkslieder (Begleitung einstudiert); Mozart: Amoll-Sonate, Linie.
Lieder by Schubert and Brahms intended for a concert, Lieder by Wolf, Brahms folk songs (rehearsed the accompaniment); Mozart: Sonata in A minor, line.

Konzertprogramm: op. 101Schenker's Erläuterungsausgabe of Beethoven's Op. 101 (published August 1921) includes a substantial analysis that was, according to his diary, dictated in part on 19 October 1919 and completed on 20 June 1920 ‒ thus during the 1919/20 saison. wiederholt; Bagatellen op. 33 Fdur, Asdur; op. 119: Ddur; Sonate op. 81 wiederholt; Bagatellen op. 119 Adur; op. 126: Bdur, Cmoll.Schenker is presumably referring to the Bagatelles Op. 119, Nos. 11 (B major) and 5 (C minor). Op. 126 does not include pieces in these keys. Mondscheinsonate neu; Wut über den
verlorenen Groschen, neu.

Concert program: Op. 101 revisited; Bagatelles Op. 33 F major, A major; Op. 119 D major; Sonata Op. 81a revisited; Bagatelles Op. 119 A major; Op. 126: B major, C minor. "Moonlight" Sonata, new; Rage over a
Lost Penny, new.

Chopin, Walzer Desdur, Cismoll, Asdur, wiederholt; Bach: Cmoll-Präludium u. Fuge wiederholt; Beethoven: Sonate Cmoll op. 10; Fdur op. 10. Schubert: Wanderer-Phantasie; Brahms: Konzert Dmoll nach der Partitur, StufenFrom Schenker's diary, 29 May 1920: "Frl. Kahn sträubt sich gegen die Linie, ihr liege es besser Vollendung anzustreben wo sie sie erreichen könne u. sie meint, dies wäre der Fall bei Stufen u. Stimmführung." ("Miss Kahn resists the Urlinie, saying she would do better to strive for mastery where she can achieve it and thinks that would be the case with scale-steps and voice-leading."); Mozart: Phantasie Cmoll; Weber: Rondo Cdur.

Chopin, Waltzes in D major, C minor, A major, revisited; Bach: C minor Prelude & Fugue revisited; Beethoven: Sonata in C minor, Op. 10; F major, Op. 10. Schubert: Wanderer Fantasy; Brahms: Concerto in D minor according to the orchestral score, scale-steps; Mozart: Fantasy in C minor; Weber: Rondo in C major.
wiederholt: Mondscheinsonate; Brahms: op. 118. Chopin: Präludium Fmoll, neu.
Revisited: "Moonlight" Sonata; Brahms: Op. 118. Chopin: Prelude in F minor, new.

Bach: Präludium Cmoll, Bd. II, Linie u. Harmonien; Präludium Cmoll, Bd. I; Choral „Herzliebster”, dazu Riemann; MischungenThat is, combinations of the five species of strict counterpoint. See Bridges to Free Composition in Schenker, Counterpoint, Book 2.; Polonaise Cismoll, Linie.For an amusing account of a lesson on this piece, see the diary entry from 9 June 1920.

Schubert: Impromptu Asdur; Beethoven: Sonate Dmoll. Philipp Em. Bach neu: Sonate Cdur, Rondo Hmoll; Seb. Bach: Fuge Esmoll, Bd. I; wiederholt Bach-Busoni:
Chaconne; Bach: kleines Präludi um en ; neu. wiederholt Haydn: Fmoll; wiederholt Chopin: Etude Cismoll; Brahms: Intermezzo op. 119 Emoll.

Schubert: Impromptu in A major; Beethoven: Sonata in D minor. C.P.E. Bach, new: Sonata in C major, Rondo in B minor; J.S. Bach: Fugue in E minor, Book I; revisited Bach-Busoni:
Chaconne; Bach: Little Preludes, new. Revisited Haydn: F minor; revisited Chopin: Etude in C minor; Brahms: Intermezzo Op. 119 E minor.

Brahms: Intermezzo Esdur, neu; Intermezzo Cismoll; Chopin: Polonaise Cismoll, neu; Schumann: Des Abends; wiederholt Chopin Etude Cismoll; Bach: kleines Präludium No 1; Schumann: Waldscenen: Vogel als Prophet; Eintritt in den Wald; Einsame Blumen.

Brahms: Intermezzo in E major, new; Intermezzo in C minor; Chopin: Polonaise in C minor, new; Schumann: Des Abends; revisited Chopin Etude in C minor; Bach: Little Prelude No. 1; Schumann: Waldscenen: Vogel als Prophet; Eintritt in den Wald; Einsame Blumen.
wiederholt Chopin Prélude Gdur; Etude Gismoll; Brahms: Klavier-Violin-Sonate Dmoll.
Revisited Chopin Prelude in G major; Etude in G minor; Brahms Sonata for Violin and Piano in D minor.

vierst. Satz; Autograph Brahms op. 117,According to Schenker's diary, he received photographs of Op. 117 from Hans Weisse on 24 February 1920, the day before he finished dictating an essay on the Intermezzo in E major, Op. 117, No. 1. The essay survives as OC 34/83‒105. Beethoven 101 Autograph gezeigt; Beethoven: Sonate Dmoll, Linie; Fingersatz zu Schumanns Phantasiestücken;
geht vollständig zum Klavier über.This remark suggests Frl. Schaab discontinued her counterpoint studies at the end of 1919/20. The entry on her lessons in 1920/21 seems to confirm this, as it lists only piano repertoire and makes no further mention of counterpoint.

Four-voiced counterpoint; autograph of Brahms Op. 117, showed autograph of Beethoven Op. 101; Beethoven: Sonata in D minor, line; fingering for Schumann's Fantasy Pieces;
goes over entirely to piano.

Beethoven: Sonate Bdur op. 22, 1. Satz; Brahms: Cmoll-Quartett; Beethoven: Asdur op. 26; Chopin: mehrere Mazurken; Beethoven: Klavier-Violin-Sonate Gdur, Linie; Mozart: Streichquintett, 1. Satz, Linie; Mozart: Requiem: Konfutatis, Schluss: a‒as‒g; Lacrimosa; Brahms: Quintett Fmoll, 1. Satz; Beethoven: Sonate Edur, 1. Satz; Brahms: Quintett Fmoll, Scherzo u. letzter Satz; Beethoven: Sonate Esdur quasi una Phantasia; Mondscheinsonate. Bach: Fuge Fmoll, II. Bd.No paragraph-break in source.

Beethoven: Sonate Esdur, letzter Satz; Brahms: Intermezzo, AutographPresumably this was from the autograph of Brahms's Three Intermezzi, Op. 117, mentioned in the entry on Schaab's lessons from this semester. According to Schenker's diary, he received photographs of Op. 117 from Weisse on 24 February 1920 and finished dictating an essay on the Intermezzo in E major, Op. 117/1, the next day. The essay survives as OC 34/83‒105.; Choral „Gelobet seist du”; Beethoven: Sonate Gdur op. 31, No 1, 1. Satz; Scarlatti, Volksausgabe No 41 Cdur, No 49 Gdur Fdur ; Barth-
Ausgabe No 52 Fmoll, No 54 AmollSchenker is surely referring to the two editions of Scarlatti's sonatas that are preserved in the Oster Collection, namely the Breinkopf & Härtel "Volksausgabe" (score 89) and the version edited by Heinrich Barth and published by Universal Edition (OC scores 86‒88).; Brahms: Violinkonzert, Stelle bei F; Scarlatti: No 52,Presumably Schenker is referring to OC score 89 here, as No. 52 from score 88 has already been cited. The annotations seem to confirm this, as No. 52 from score 89 has numerous stems, slurs, and careted scale-degree numbers that may refer to "nodal points," while most of the markings in No. 52 from Score 88 deal with performance-related matters such as articulation and fingering. 32, Cdur,"Cdur" may be an extension of the reference to OC score 89, No. 32 (K. 15 in C major), or it may be a reference to one of the other two sonatas in C major from the same volume (Nos. 41 and 42). All three sonatas have analytical annotations, including stems and brackets or slurs, and one of them (No. 41) has careted scale-degree numbers as well. Knotenpunkte,Schenker uses this term to describe linear progressions, especially intersecting fourth- and fifth-progressions, in his analyses of Beethoven's Fifth Symphony (Tonwille 1, 27, see Figure 7) and of Beethoven's Piano Sonata Op. 101 (Op. 101 Erläuterungsausgabe, 48‒49, see Figure 27). The Fifth Symphony article announces that nodal points will be discussed further in "Freier Satz," and although the final version of Der freie Satz makes no mention of nodal points, a draft entitled "Von Knotenpunkten bei der Horizontalisierung" does survive as OC 79/854‒856. auch No 35; Beethoven: Sonate Gdur op. 31, No 1, 2. Satz; Schubert: Walzer, Deutsche Tänze No 1; Beethoven: Sonate op. 14, Durchführung, Linie, letzter Satz; Beethoven: Cmoll: Pathetique; Bach: Präludium Fisdur, I. Bd.; Choral „Ein' feste Burg ist unser Gott” ‒ dazu Wagner u. Choral; Beethoven: Sonate Dmoll, 1. Satz; Bach Choral „Aus trüber tiefer Not”; Beethoven: Appassionata noch einmal 1. Satz; Beethoven: Sonate Ddur, Scherzo u. letzter Satz; Dwořak: Legenden vierhändig; Beethoven: Klavier-Violin-Sonate, Adagio; Beethoven: Wut über den verlorenen Groschen; Beethoven: Sonate Dmoll, letzter Satz;No paragraph-break in source.

Beethoven: Sonata in B major Op. 22, first movement; Brahms: Quartet in C minor; Beethoven A major Op. 26; Chopin: several Mazurkas; Beethoven: Sonata for Violin and Piano in G major, line; Mozart: String Quintet, first movement, line; Mozart: Requiem: Confutatis, ending: A‒A‒G; Lacrimosa; Brahms: Quintet in F minor, first movement; Beethoven: Sonata in E major, first movement; Brahms: Quintet in F minor, Scherzo and last movement; Beethoven: Sonata Quasi una Fantasia in E major; "Moonlight" Sonata. Bach: Fugue in F minor, Book II.

Beethoven: Sonata in E major, last movement; Brahms: Intermezzo, autograph; chorale "Gelobet seist du" ; Beethoven: Sonata in G major, Op. 31, No. 1, first movement; Scarlatti, Volksausgabe No. 41 C major, No. 49 G major F major ; Barth
edition No. 52 F minor, No. 54 A minor; Brahms: Violin Concerto, rehearsal F; Scarlatti: No. 52, 32, C major, nodal points, also No. 35; Beethoven: Sonata in G major Op. 31, No. 1, second movement; Schubert: Waltzes, German Dances No. 1; Beethoven: Sonata Op. 14, development section, line, last movement; Beethoven: C minor: "Pathétique"; Bach: Prelude in F major, Book I; chorale "Ein' feste Burg ist unser Gott" ‒ along with Wagner and the chorale; Beethoven: Sonata in D minor, first movement; Bach chorale "Aus trüber tiefer Not"; Beethoven: "Appassionata" once again the first movement; Beethoven: Sonata in D major, Scherzo and last movement; Dvořák: Legends played four-hands; Beethoven: Sonata for Piano and Violin, Adagio; Beethoven: Rage over a Lost Penny; Beethoven: Sonata in D minor, last movement;
